name: Strychninum
Relationship: Compare: EUCALYPTUS (neutralizes ill effects of STRYCHNINE). STRYCHN. ARS. (Paresis in the aged, relaxed musculature. Prostration. Psoriasis; chronic diarrhoea with paralytic symptoms; compensatory hypertrophy of heart with beginning fatty degeneration; marked dyspnoea when lying down; oedema of lower extremities, urine scanty, high specific gravity, heavily loaded with glucose. Diabetes. 6X trit.). STRYCHN. ET. FERR. CIT. (chlorotic and paralytic conditions; dyspepsia, with vomiting of ingesta; 2x and 3X trit.); STRYCHNINE NIT. (2x and 3X. Said to remove craving for alcohol. Use for two weeks); STRYCHNINE. SULPH. (Gastric atony); STRYCHN. VALERIN. (exhaustion of brain-power; women of high nervous erethism; 2x trit.). Compare: CICUTA; ARNICA (tetanus).
Modalities: Worse: morning; touch; noise; motion; after meals

Eyes: Spasmodic contraction of ocular muscles; twitching and trembling of lids
Fever: Perspiration in a stream down head and chest
Head: Vertigo, with roaring in ears
Over-irritability
Restless
Full and bursting headache, with heat in eyes
Itching of scalp and nape
Jerking of head forwards
Scalp sore
Back: Back stiff; violent jerks in spinal column
Sharp pain in nape and down spine
Face: Jaws stiffened; lower jaw spasmodically closed
Respiratory: Sharp, contractive pains in muscles of chest
Female: Any touch on body excites a voluptuous sensation
Skin: Itching of whole body, especially nose
Throat: Violent itching in roof of mouth
Dry, contracted; feeling of a lump
Burning along and spasms of oesophagus
Abdomen: Sharp pain in abdominal muscles, griping pain in bowels
Extremities: Tetanic convulsions and opisthotonos; spasms provoked by slightest touch and attempt to move
Ears: Hearing very acute; burning, itching, and roaring in ears

details: Its primary function is to stimulate the motor centers and the reflex action of the spinal cord. Homeopathic to spasms of muscles, cramps from an undue reflex excitability of the cord, spasms of the bladder, etc. Strychnine stimulates the central nervous system, mental activities, special senses rendered more acute. Respiration increased. All reflexes are made more active. Stiffness in muscles and face and neck. Opisthotonos. Tetanic convulsions with opisthotonos. The muscles relax between paroxysms; worse slightest touch, sound, odor. Influences more directly the spinal cord and is less appropriate in visceral derangements than Nux. TETANUS. Explosive nervousness. The pains and sensations come SUDDENLY and return at INTERVALS.Gastric atony; STRYCHN. VALERIN. Exhaustion of brain-power; women of high nervous erethism; 2x trit.
dosage: Third to thirtieth potency. For non-homeopathic use, to produce its direct physiological effects in paralysis the dose will range from one-fiftieth to one-twentieth of a grain, repeated three times a day. Under twelve years of age, one-fiftieth to one-hundredth of a grain. STRYCHN., hypodermically, is capable of arresting progressive muscular atrophy, and is a certain stimulant to the respiratory centers, and is useful in embarrassed breathing, in the course of pneumonia especially. Is an antidote to Chloral, used in asphyxia from gas and chloroform and early stages of Opium
